body: As I understand it, if I do this, when a group with a spec ID matching the GUID is encountered and joined or created it should automatically use the matching object.
Does anyone have any pointers or examples of using this infrastructure for PeerGroup implementation?
Should I be listing a related PeerGroup implementing object here with a GUID in net.jxta.platform.Module ?
Also, some general information on the META-INF.services mechanism in Java would be helpful.
For the most part, I approached JXTA with a just make it work attitude.
I see some new new mechanisms that are using the META-INF.services infrastructure of Java.
I should be able to just manually tie a PeerGroup object to the group but this new method using META-INF seems to be a lot easier to manage.
My first step would be a basic creation of a custom PeerGroup .
I have been working with JXTA 2.3 for the last year or so for a peer-to-peer computing platform I am developing.
I used it to jumpstart creating and managing my peer-to-peer overlay network and providing basic communication services.
I would like to use it in a more JXTA way since I am making changes to move to 2.5 anyway.
I am migrating to JXTA 2.5 and in the process I am trying to clean up a lot of my use of JXTA .
title: Getting started with a custom JXTA PeerGroup

body: I looked into it and discovered that my default TimeZone is being set to: _CODE_ Rather than the Pacific time zone.
If someone knows such a setting, that would be awesome, but for now this is a decent workaround.
Since the generic -8 offset has no daylight savings info, it's of course not using it, but the question is, where do I tell Java to use Pacific time zone when it starts up?
I am running a Tomcat application, and I need to display some time values.
Is there a configuration file I can update to tell the JRE to use Pacific with all the associated daylight savings time information?
However, I still think there is a better solution... there should be a configuration for Java somewhere that says what timezone it is using, or how it is grabbing the timezone.
A coworker suggested I update JAVA_OPTS in my /etc/profile to include "-Duser.timezone=US/Pacific", which worked (I also saw CATALINA_OPTS, which I updated as well).
Ok, here's an update.
I am running on Ubuntu Hardy Heron, upgraded from Gutsy Gibbon.

This is further indicated when I try to print the default time zone's display name , and it comes up "GMT-08:00", which seems to indicate to me that it is not correctly set to the US Pacific time zone.
I am using 1.5, and it is most definitely a DST problem.
Unfortunately, the time is coming up an hour off.
My belief is it is generically set to -8 offset rather than the specific Pacific timezone.
Actually, I just exported the change into the variables rather than use the new /etc/profile (a reboot later will pick up the changes and I will be golden).
As you can see, the time zone is set to not use daylight savings.
The time on my machine shows correctly, so it doesn't seem to be an OS-wide misconfiguration.
I'm NOT looking for a programmatic solution, it should be a configuration solution.
title: Java Time Zone is messed up

body: I was hoping someone could help me out with a problem I'm having using the java search function in Eclipse on a particular project.
Unfortunately, that's not the case in my setup, so I'm still stuck.

The only reference I've been able to find on Google for the problem is at http://www.crazysquirrel.com/computing/java/eclipse/error-during-java-search.jspx , but unfortunately his solution (closing, deleting class files, restarting) did not work for me.
_CODE_ Also just found this thread - http://www.myeclipseide.com/PNphpBB2-viewtopic-t-20067.html - which indicates the same problem may occur when the project name contains a period.
When using the java search on one particular project, I get an error message saying Class file name must end with .class (see stack trace below).
This does not seem to be happening on all projects, just one particular one, so perhaps there's something I should try to get rebuilt?
I have already tried Project -> Clean ... and Closing Eclipse, deleting all the built class files and restarting Eclipse to no avail.
_CODE_ Thanks McDowell, closing and opening the project seems to have fixed it (at least for now).
If anyone can suggest something to try, or there's any more info I can gather which might help track it's down, I'd greatly appreciate the pointers.
title: Class file name must end with .class exception in Java Search

body: Is it used for rounding in java.math.BigDecimal .
Please let me know if you have any idea on this.
If yes why does not it round the decimal digits but even mantissa part.
From API docs, I came to know that it follows the standard specified in ANSI X3.274-1996 and ANSI X3.274-1996/AM 1-2000 specifications but I did not get them to read online.
Recently I tried understanding the use of java.math.MathContext but failed to understand properly.
title: Use of java.math.MathContext

body: I have intended to use a StAX parser ( javax.xml.stream.XMLStreamReader ) to read in each event, see if it was one I wanted to change, and then pass it straight on to the StAX writer ( javax.xml.stream.XMLStreamReader ) if no changes were required.
I'm currently trying to read in an XML file, make some minor changes (alter the value of some attributes), and write it back out again.
Is there something I'm missing that makes it easy to write out a very similar XML document to the one you read in with StAX?
Unfortunately, that doesn't look to be so simple - The writer has no way to take an event type and a parser object, only methods like writeAttribute and writeStartElement .

Obviously I could write a big switch statement with a case for every possible type of element which can occur in an XML document, and just write it back out again, but it seems like a lot of trouble for something which seems like it should be simple.
title: Small modification to an XML document using StAX

body: I have also verified that all database connections are being closed properly.
I have a tomcat instance setup but the database connection I have configured in context.xml keeps dying after periods of inactivity.

You should consider either expiring and/or testing connection validity before use in your application, increasing the server configured values for client timeouts, or using the Connector/J connection property 'autoReconnect=true' to avoid this problem.
Here is the configuration in context.xml: _CODE_ I am using autoReconnect=true like the error says to do, but the connection keeps dying.
When I check the logs I get the following error: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.CommunicationsException: The last packet successfully received from the server was68051 seconds ago.
I have never seen this happen before.
The last packet sent successfully to the server was 68051 seconds ago, which is longer than the server configured value of 'wait_timeout'.
title: Java+Tomcat, Dying database connection?

body: This isn't as useful as it sounds because it's not clear how I'm supposed to use this information to write a Java client.
I'm not in that position.
If the web service request isn't signed according to the policy then it is rejected by the service.
Has anyone done this successfully?
The information that I received from the service provider included WSDL, a policyCache.config file, some sample C# code, and a sample application that can successfully call the service.
I'm trying to use Apache Axis2 and I can't find any instructions on how I'm supposed to use the policyCahce.config file and the WSDL to generate a client.
The web service implements the WS-Security stack (either WSE 2 or WSE 3, it's not clear from the information I have).
I need to call a web service written in .NET from Java.

There are several examples that I have found on the Web but in all cases the authors of the examples had control of both the service and the client and so were able to make tweaks on both sides in order to get it to work.
title: Calling .NET Web Service (WSE 2/3, WS-Security) from Java

body: And then just write each line back with _CODE_ Summary: samjudson : This is only a difference in text files, where UNIX uses a single Line Feed (LF) to signify a new line, Windows uses a Carriage Return/Line Feed (CRLF) and Mac uses just a CR.
You'll need to use chown/chmod to make sure the correct users have access to them.

I'll probably need something to determine the current format and something to transform it into the other format.If it's just the newline thats the big difference then I'm considering just reading the files with the java.io.
Cheekysoft However, another set of problems that you may come across can be related to single/multi-byte character encodings.
This may result in files that are supposed to be hidden now becoming visible on the client machines.
to which Cebjyre elaborates: OS X uses LF, the same as UNIX - MacOS 9 and below did use CR though Mo There could also be a difference in character encoding for national characters.
On windows, it's a filesystem flag that you probably don't have easy access to.
As far as I know, they are able to handle both with readLine.
If you see strange unexpected chars (not at end-of-line) then this could be the reason.
McDowell In addition to the new-line differences, the byte-order mark can cause problems if files are treated as Unicode on Windows.
Especially if you see square boxes, question marks, upside-down question marks, extra characters or unexpected accented characters.
Help for java coding Cheekysoft When writing to files or reading from files (that you are in control of), it is often worth specifying the encoding to use, as most Java methods allow this.
There exists tools to help with the problem: pauldoo If you are just interested in the content of text files, then yes the line endings are different.
I am not sure, what windows default encoding is.
I need to automate the translation between unix/windows before the files get delivered to the system in our "transportsystem".
Cheekysoft As pauldoo suggests, tools like dos2unix can be very useful.
There is no "unix-encoding" but many linux-variants use UTF-8 as the default encoding.
Sadie On unix, files that start with a .
Take a look at something like dos2unix, it may be of help here.
You will probably find, when you copy files onto a unix system, that the files now belong to the user that did the copying and have limited rights.
are hidden.
File permissions vary between the two.
We have a system that has been moved from a windows machine to a unix machine and are having troubles with the format.
However, also ensuring that the system locale matches can save a lot of pain
Note that these may be on your linux/unix system as fromdos or tofrodos, or perhaps even as the general purpose toolbox recode.
Mac OS (which is also a unix) uses its own encoding (macroman).
Am I correct in assuming that the only difference between "windows files" and "unix files" is the linebreak?
title: Differences between unix and windows files

body: Naturally, I could create a new List<String> and loop through the list calling String.valueOf() for each integer, but I was wondering if there was a better (read: more automatic ) way of doing it?
I have a list of integers, List<Integer> and I'd like to convert all the integer objects into Strings, thus finishing up with a new List<String> .
title: Converting List<Integer> to List<String>

body: Usually format would be (calls without using .
The RFC for a Java class is set of all methods that can be invoked in response to a message to an object of the class or by some method in the class.
Load C using classloader and use reflection to get the count of methods.
First level only.
We need to count the number of method calls from the class.
RFC = M + R where M = Number of methods in the class.R = Total number of other methods directly invoked from the M. Thinking C is the .class and J is the .java file of which we need to calculate RFC.
Let me try it.
class J{ a(){} b(){} c(){   e1.e();   e1.f();   e1.g(); } h(){   i.k();   i.j();  }  m(){}  n(){   i.o();   i.p();   i.p();   i.p();  }} here M=6and R=9  (Don't worry about call inside a loop.
Calculating R is not direct.
For calculating R I must use regex.

are not counted) [variable_name].[method_name]([zero or more parameters]); or [variable_name].[method_name]([zero or more parameters]) with out semicolon when call return is directly becomes parameter to another method.or [variable_name].[method_name]([zero or more parameters]).method2(); this becomes two method calls What other patterns of the method call can you think of?
It's considered as a single call) Calculating M is easy.
Is there any other way other than using RegEx that can be used to calculate R. UPDATE: @McDowell Looks like using BCEL I can simplify the whole process.
title: Algorithm to perform RFC calculation in Java
